description: From Middle English pynsor, from Old French pinceure, pinchure, from pincier (“to pinch”).

entries.meaning: Any object that resembles one half of a pair of pincers.

verbs.description: pincer (third-person singular simple present pincers, present participle pincering, simple past and past participle pincered)

entries.meaning: (transitive, sometimes figurative) To surround with a pincer attack.
examples: After considering all frontal counteroffensive alternatives, Heublein rejected them as detrimental to its profits and came up with a brilliant pincering maneuver. It raised the price of Smirnoff by one dollar, effectively preventing segment diffusion,  […]
